unnormalised: New Delhi: A recent analysis of govt. data reveals critical insights into healthcare access and affordability across India. The study, conducted by the National Health Authority (NHA), indicates that approximately 65% of rural households still face significant financial barriers in accessing quality medical care. This is despite the Ayushman Bharat scheme, which aims to provide health insurance coverage of Rs. 5 lakh per family per year.
normalised: New Delhi: A recent analysis of government data reveals critical insights into healthcare access and affordability across India. The study, conducted by the N-H-A, indicates that approximately sixty five percent of rural households still face significant financial barriers in accessing quality medical care. This is despite the Ayushman Bharat scheme, which aims to provide health insurance coverage of rupee five lakh per family per year.

unnormalised: The report also highlights disparities in healthcare spending. On avg, families in urban areas spend Rs. 12,000 annually on healthcare, compared to Rs. 5,000 in rural areas. Private hospitals account for nearly 70% of inpatient care expenditures, while govt. hospitals see a larger share of outpatient visits. A significant percentage, around 45%, of medical expenses are still paid out-of-pocket, pushing many families into debt.

unnormalised: Furthermore, the analysis delves into electronic health records (EHR) adoption rates. Only 30% of hospitals, both govt. and private, have fully implemented EHR systems. Data security remains a major concern, with only 15% of hospitals reporting compliance with national data protection standards. Experts suggest that incentivizing EHR adoption with financial grants and addressing data privacy concerns are crucial steps.

unnormalised: In related news, the ministry of health has announced a budgetary allocation of Rs. 86,175 crore for the upcoming fiscal year to improve healthcare infrastructure and accessibility across the country. This includes provisions for upgrading existing hospitals, establishing new primary health centers, and strengthening digital health initiatives. The goal is to reduce out-of-pocket healthcare expenditures to below 30% by 2025.
